Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
Not to mention they posted an official medium article with about half of it talking about Luke and a completely unrelated event in an attempt to discredit someone who simply verified the bug. 
Again, footnote 2 shows you dont know if Google saved these seeds, and the screenshot of the 400 error says nothing about if this was Always the case, or if it is just the case right now. How long has this bug been in the app? How long has it been sending seeds to Google, and at what point did these start returning 400s instead of being processed? Did the spellcheck feature always NOT work in the app, or did it break sometime after it was created. 
For all these questions and your own admitted uncertainty in if Google actually saved this stuff, you sure are certain about trying to drag open devs through the mud, and publicly claiming you're going to sue a panicking guy who lost his money and felt he was robbed by you. Anyone who works in customer service is used to upset customers throwing around threats, they are under no obligation to act professionally, you on the other hand are.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: until coinimi wallet is open sourced and then has some time to be verified, i cannot recommend anybody to use it at all, despite whatever assurances are given

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I cant see how that makes me irresponsible. We have the technical facts that clearly show privkey data went to where it shouldnt have. whether it was then actually exploited or not is a he said/she said debate which I dont really want to get into. The fact is that passphrases were sent to external servers, which is worse than if passphrases were sent to coinimiservers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: being closed source, there is no way to know how many other issues are buried

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the security promise of coinimi is that it is as secure as central exchanges, then upon that level of security, maybe people can decide to use it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is the mobile client open source?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is there a guarantee that there are no more bugs?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with open source there is no guarantee, but at least other coders can look at it. with closed source, well, it can be sending your passphrase in for spellchecking to google servers and nobody would know it without detailed analysis

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at least not when passphrases are involved

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for infrastructure things without passphrases, it seems closed source is not any big issue. probably most people dont have all the source code for their ISP, VPN or VPS provider

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
I personally think the issue isn't necessarily the closed source aspect, people have varying levels of trust in brands and companies, but how the issue was handled by customer service was the problem. They took someone who knew it was closed source and entrusted it anyway, and held him at arms length while he panicked over losing funds. 
Almost every message they sent him was accusatory and short, or some type of command. There was no personal understanding, they even quoted his word "stolen" to openly show they didn't believe him. Basically saying "you're a scammer, and your life changing issue doesn't mean shit to us, but Skype with us and bring all forms of ID." Which read as a challenge to a scammer, not as a company trying to resolve a customer's issue. They didn't even have to promise a refund, although he said that's what he wanted and he gave them an ultimatum (blackmailer isn't the way you describe customers either!) Anyone who has been in business knows that upset customers say shit they dont always mean and make threats, the best bet is to LISTEN, EMPATHIZE, and cool the situation down to get to the real problem and try and resolve it if you can. I could teach a course about how Coinomi botched this customer service and lead to a forced ultimatum and tons of negative press.

Then again @Deleted User you may be right about closed source, I'm a business person more than I'm a programmer, so I mostly see business problems/solutions. Basically that saying, when you're a hammer all you see is nails. Lol

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Yea the Twitter account is one of the most unprofessional I've seen in any industry. Posting tweets saying they're going to sue someone, getting into a prolonged argument in dozens of posts, then deleting things they said in haste which were legal threats or contradictory. Whoever's running that Twitter needs to put down the phone and take a walk to cool off and breathe

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Customer care is one of the hardest jobs, everyone blames you for every issue, you get threatened a lot. It's all about defusing situations, not letting ultimatums and threats become reality

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Yeah, the deny till you die strategy does not work, blaming anyone else other then yourself is not helping either...

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
I usually started by showing that I'm a person and not just an automated response lol approaching them as a person and showing that you absolutely understand how stressful the situation is and that you are personally going to work to resolve it, then say what it is you are doing and why you are asking particular questions, not just "Please provide this" "we are working on your claim." "please report responsibly" or w.e. Considering Warith believed someone at Coinomi backdoored him, it's probably best to break the image of Coinomi into individuals, the one he's speaking with being one who likely had no control over the issue and wants only to resolve it.
I'm also assuming Coinomi isn't reading any of these anymore, which is a shame, we're basically giving customer service 101, which based on their current twitter posting, they desperately need.
